This toolkit provides materials and templates for implementing the AGEP-NC (Alliances for Graduate Education and the Professoriate - North Carolina) model of change to promote the success of Latino\/a, Black and Indigenous American doctoral students in completing the degree and preparing for faculty roles.<\/p>

Graduate program directors, department heads and deans will find example actions, sample language for policies, and videos of AGEP-NC community members discussing their experiences and how they approached the process of making change.<\/p>

The section for faculty fellows includes checklists for conducting a study of how students move through their doctoral programs, as well as examples of sensemaking activities to engage their faculty colleagues and guidelines and examples of departmental plans that have been developed by other participating departments.<\/p>

If you wish to adapt the AGEP-NC model to your own institution, the section titled \"Tools for Administering the AGEP-NC Program\" provides information about the AGEP-NC model of change, templates for recruiting and selecting faculty fellows, baseline data, example curricula for faculty fellows, and links to articles about different aspects of the AGEP-NC project. Survey instruments for assessing the practices and climate in doctoral programs are also provided in the last section of the toolkit. Finally, we offer a 7-hour workshop on adapting the AGEP-NC model to your institution.<\/p>"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"},{"id":"3d737a4","elType":"widget","settings":{"space":{"unit":"px","size":25,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"5e609f9","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"b261aa0","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"6818b87","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Tools for Making Change
","__globals__":{"title_color":"globals\/colors?id=secondary"}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"f381001","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"2e06675","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"8daa96b","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Tools for Deans","size":"medium","__globals__":{"title_color":"globals\/colors?id=secondary"}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"836a47e","elType":"widget","settings":{"tabs":[{"tab_title":"Faculty Searches","tab_content":"

  • Best Practices for Recruiting and Retaining Faculty of Color<\/a><\/span> - This document is a compilation of ideas culled from departmental plans to recruit and retain diverse faculty.<\/li>
  • Video of Dean Jeff Braden, NC State College of Humanities and Social Sciences, discussing the effectiveness of departmental plans to recruit and retain diverse faculty.<\/a><\/span><\/li>
  • Video of Dean Braden charging a search committee, emphasizing the College commitment to diversity and providing insight into how unconscious bias plays out in faculty searches.<\/a><\/span><\/li><\/ul>","_id":"c5f3ea3"},{"tab_title":"Culture change in higher education","tab_content":"
    • Adrianna Kezar webinar on culture change and competing priorities<\/a><\/span><\/li>
    • Kezar and Eckel, 2002. Examining the institutional transformation process: The importance of sensemaking, interrelated strategies, and balance.<\/a><\/span><\/li><\/ul>","_id":"d8f2a37"},{"_id":"4cbc628","tab_title":"Examples of college diversity committees","tab_content":"
      • NC State College of Humanities and Social Sciences Diversity Action Committee<\/a><\/span><\/li>
      • NC State College of Sciences Committee on Diversity, Equity and Inclusion<\/a><\/span><\/li><\/ul>"},{"_id":"7f04c67","tab_title":"Example college values statement","tab_content":"
        UNC Charlotte College of Computing and Informatics Vision and Mission<\/h6>

        Video of Dean Fatma Mili discussing developing a College values statment<\/a><\/span><\/p>

        CCI Vision<\/h6>

        A World with Equity in Computing and Humanity in Technology<\/p>

        CCI Mission<\/h6>
        To empower people to shape the future through computing education, research, and engagement.<\/div>
        \u00a0<\/div>
        Guiding Principles<\/h6>
        • We value intellectual curiosity at the service of scientific knowledge and sustainable progress<\/li>
        • We strive to understand and consider the ethical implications of our discipline<\/li>
        • We strive for equity of experience and outcome for all<\/li><\/ul><\/div>"}],"__globals__":{"tab_active_color":"globals\/colors?id=primary"}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"toggle"},{"id":"09ffc13","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Tools for Department Heads and Graduate Directors","size":"medium","__globals__":{"title_color":"globals\/colors?id=secondary"}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"a91d8ac","elType":"widget","settings":{"tabs":[{"tab_title":"Example diversity committee charge","tab_content":"
          • Biological Sciences, UNC Charlotte<\/a><\/span><\/li>
          • Biomedical Engineering, UNC Chapel Hill and NC State<\/a><\/span><\/li>
          • Marine, Earth and Atmospheric Sciences, NC State
            • Community Climate Committee<\/a><\/span><\/li>
            • Diversity Committee<\/a><\/span><\/li><\/ul><\/li><\/ul>","_id":"4c03fd6"},{"tab_title":"Video: Department head discussing department culture and sensemaking activities","tab_content":"

              Derek Aday, Head of the Department of Applied Ecology at NC State, discussing how his department engaged in debating approaches to enhancing the departmental climate.<\/p>

              [video width=\"1280\" height=\"720\" mp4=\"http:\/\/agep-nc.org\/wp-content\/uploads\/2022\/03\/Derek-Aday-Engaging-Faculty-in-Sense-Making.mp4\"][\/video]<\/p>","_id":"cc430a4"},{"_id":"8e3b497","tab_title":"Example language for tenure and promotion guidelines","tab_content":"

              Department of Applied Ecology, NC State<\/strong><\/p>

              From AEC RPT RUL 05.67.23<\/em><\/p>

              2.7. In recognition of the central importance of diversity in our field, we consider the work of scholars and teachers to diversify science and science engagement to be as great a contribution (in the context of promotion and tenure) as research, teaching or extension. Examples of such efforts, which transcend the traditional categories of contribution, include a) mentoring students from underrepresented groups, b) scholarly work related to diversity and inclusivity, c) participation in, and especially leadership in, training focused on diversity in science and d) engagement and extension focused on underrepresented communities.<\/em><\/p>

              Department of Molecular and Structural Biochemistry, NC State<\/strong><\/p>

              NC State University\u2019s Department of Molecular and Structural Biochemistry includes these statements in their teaching, research, and service performance standards (https:\/\/policies.ncsu.edu\/rule\/rul-05-67-703\/<\/a>), respectively:\u00a0<\/p>

              • Teaching Standards: \u201cAll faculty are expected to create and maintain an inclusive learning environment.\u201d<\/em><\/li>
              • Research Standards: \u201cAttracting graduate students into a specific research program, success of graduate students and other trainees, and establishment of an inclusive training culture are indications of the stature of an individual\u2019s research program.\u201d<\/em><\/li>
              • Service Standards: Evidence includes\u2026 \u201cExtramural service including but not limited to science education in the community, fostering infrastructure development to support success of underrepresented minorities, and other outreach activities.\u201d<\/em><\/li><\/ul>"},{"_id":"67dcd72","tab_title":"Example language for faculty annual reports","tab_content":"

                DIVERSITY ACTIVITIES:<\/strong><\/p>

                Please describe activities related to diversity, equity and inclusion at either the personal (off campus), department, college, or university level, or in the discipline.<\/p>"},{"_id":"a1a44f8","tab_title":"Teaching Module on Communication Styles for Mentors and Mentees","tab_content":"

                Applied Ecology Communication Styles Module<\/a><\/p>"},{"_id":"560b915","tab_title":"Individual Development Plans for graduate students and postdocs","tab_content":"

                • Individual Development Plan (IDP) designed by AAAS for your Post Doctoral Career<\/a><\/span><\/p><\/li>

                • Watch a video out of UCSF on how to formulate an IDP<\/a><\/span><\/p><\/li>

                • An IDP from Boston University<\/a> <\/span>plus a number of useful resources students can use if they are unsure of their career path e.g. personality tests<\/p><\/li>

                • IDP for years 1-5 of doctoral studies from NC State Biochemistry<\/a><\/li><\/ul>"},{"_id":"69bfdc8","tab_title":"Example Syllabus for First Year Orientation Course","tab_content":"

                  Introduction to Biological Research<\/p>

                  Syllabus with links to all course materials: AEC502 Detailed Schedule Fall 2022<\/a><\/p>

                  Topics:<\/p>

                  • Tips on succeeding in graduate school<\/li>
                  • Building your team - advisor, committee, your peers, and you!<\/li>
                  • NCSU Library virtual tour of resources<\/li>
                  • Developing research ideas and testable hypothesis<\/li>
                  • Scientific writing<\/li>
                  • Grant proposal writing<\/li>
                  • Grant proposal review process<\/li>
                  • Panel Review of Students' NSF GRFP proposals<\/li>
                  • Diversity, Equity and Inclusivity<\/li>
                  • Science communication<\/li>
                  • Publishing and reviewing manuscripts<\/li>
                  • Safety and mentor-mentee communication<\/li><\/ul>

                    \u00a0<\/p>"},{"_id":"98458f2","tab_title":"Expectations and Responsibilities for Faculty Mentors and Graduate Students","tab_content":"

                    • SUNY College of Environmental Science and Forestry Expectations and Responsibilities for Faculty Mentors and Graduate Students<\/a><\/li>
                    • North Carolina State University Document on Positive Graduate Education Culture<\/a><\/li>
                    • NCSU Biological and Agricultural Engineering Department Best Practices in Graduate Education for Advisors and Advisees<\/a><\/li><\/ul>"},{"_id":"0daaec7","tab_title":"An Example REU Program","tab_content":"

                      NCSU Textile Engineering, Chemistry and Science REU<\/a><\/p>"}],"__globals__":{"tab_active_color":"globals\/colors?id=primary"}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"toggle"},{"id":"2ba119a","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Tools for Implementing the AGEP-NC Model at Your University","size":"medium","__globals__":{"title_color":"globals\/colors?id=secondary"},"_element_id":"model-for-change"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"c5b540d","elType":"widget","settings":{"tabs":[{"tab_title":"Project information","tab_content":"

                      A short proceedings paper describing the AGEP-NC approach to promoting change, the project design, a schedule of activities for the first year, and lessons we learned in the first year of implementing the project:<\/p>

                      An Institutional Transformation Model to Increase Minority STEM Doctoral Student Success .<\/a> <\/span><\/p>

                      NSF abstract of the project goals and activities<\/a><\/span><\/p>

                      AGEP-NC Publications reporting on project implementation and outcomes.<\/p>

                      • Departmental initiatives across a university alliance to increase minority STEM doctoral student success<\/a><\/span><\/li>
                      • A change model that helps faculty mentor URM doctoral students for the STEM professoriate<\/a><\/span><\/li>
                      • How do departments support their underrepresented minority doctoral students? Are they doing enough?<\/a><\/span><\/li><\/ul>","_id":"e3e1bd8"},{"tab_title":"Recruiting and selecting faculty fellows","tab_content":"

                        Call for applications and nominations<\/a><\/span><\/p>

                        Department head's letter of commitment<\/a><\/span><\/p>

                        Rubric for evaluating applicants<\/a><\/span><\/p>","_id":"ea64c69"},{"_id":"d5e1560","tab_title":"Data on degree completion, alumni careers","tab_content":"

                        Collecting baseline data on numbers of students who have completed the PhD program, who are still working on their degree and who left without completing the degree, by cohort and race\/ethnicity, provides a reference for evaluating the effectiveness of your initiatives for promoting student success in degree completion.\u00a0 Data on the numbers of graduates who entered postdoctoral or faculty positions after graduation, the numbers of faculty hired and the numbers of faculty exiting by race and ethnicity are also important for tracking your progress.<\/p>

                        Example Doctoral Completion Data<\/a><\/span><\/p>"},{"_id":"d5a14e5","tab_title":"Example curricula for faculty fellows","tab_content":"

                        UNC Charlotte and NC A&T Curriculum 2019-2021<\/a><\/span><\/p>

                        UNC Charlotte and NC A&T Curriculum 2021-2022<\/a><\/span><\/p>

                        NC State Cohort II Topics and Readings<\/a><\/span><\/p>"},{"_id":"8133e50","tab_title":"Additional readings and video resources","tab_content":"

                        This links to our library of readings and videos<\/a><\/span> on the following topics:<\/p>

                        • Mentoring<\/li>
                        • Experiences of Minority Graduate Students<\/li>
                        • Promoting Institutional Change<\/li>
                        • Graduate Education and Diversity<\/li>
                        • Diverse Perspectives<\/li><\/ul>"},{"_id":"40bbf1f","tab_title":"Request a Workshop on Implementing the AGEP-NC Model","tab_content":"

                          Adopting AGEP-NC Workshop<\/span><\/strong><\/p>

                          The AGEP-NC Leadership Team would be happy to come to your institution to present a full-day or half-day workshop on implementing the AGEP-NC Model. There is no charge for the workshop, except to buy lunch for the presenters.<\/p>

                          This workshop is intended for institutions that might be interested in adopting the AGEP-NC model and trying this approach at their own institution.<\/span> It can be tailored to your institution's specific needs regarding topics covered and timing of the workshop sessions.<\/p>

                          To request a Workshop, contact Marcia Gumpertz at gumpertz@ncsu.edu<\/a>.<\/p>

                          The AGEP-NC Leadership Team gave their first Adopting AGEP-NC Workshop on October 22, 2021 at the Georgia State University School of Public Health. The workshop consisted of a half-day opening in-person workshop followed by two 1.5-hour virtual sessions.<\/span><\/p>

                          Day 1 (4 hours, in person)<\/span><\/p>

                          • Overview of aims and approach<\/span><\/li>
                          • Components of the AGEP-NC model of change, how we have <\/span>implemented them in the North Carolina Alliance and toolkit for <\/span>implementation<\/span><\/li>
                          • Listening session to understand your institution\u2019s goals and <\/span>needs, assign several questions for consideration
                            <\/span><\/li><\/ul>

                            Day 2 (1.5 hours, virtual)<\/span><\/p>

                            • Review and discussion of goals and needs at your institution; <\/span>panel discussion with AGEP-NC faculty fellows
                              <\/span><\/li><\/ul>

                              Day 3 (1.5 hours, virtual)<\/span><\/p>

                              • Surveys, mentoring results and mentor training<\/span><\/li><\/ul>

                                \u201c<\/span>We are very grateful for the time that the NC-AGEP consortium has spent sharing this mentoring model with us. During our workshop session we learned how the model has worked for them and were also able to begin to conceptualize how elements of the model might work for our School of Public Health. There was rich, thought-provoking discussion and I know I walked away excited to complete our homework and begin our next discussion on Nov. 9<\/span>th<\/span>. I see this model having elements of transformational change in how we conceptualize faculty and student mentoring<\/span>.<\/span>\u201d <\/span>\u2014 Kim Renee Ramsey White, Assistant Dean for Diversity, Equity and Inclusion, GSU School of Public Health.<\/span><\/p>

                                \u00a0<\/p>"}],"__globals__":{"tab_active_color":"globals\/colors?id=primary"}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"toggle"},{"id":"a629611","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Tools for Faculty Fellows","size":"medium","__globals__":{"title_color":"globals\/colors?id=secondary"}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"19dee9f","elType":"widget","settings":{"tabs":[{"_id":"a3014f0","tab_title":"The steps for developing a departmental plan","tab_content":"

                                1. Orient your colleagues to the AGEP-NC project and goals. An example slide deck for use in faculty meetings is provided in this section of the toolkit.<\/li>
                                2. Gather information about how students move through your doctoral programs and what difficulties they may be encountering. Two checklists for collecting this information are provided here.<\/li>
                                3. Survey faculty and doctoral students about the department's practices and climate. The survey instruments are provided in the next section of this toolkit. Share the results with your department as a means to start departmental discussions about diversity in the graduate program. An example report is given in this section.<\/li>
                                4. Develop some activities to engage your faculty colleagues in learning about the issues facing doctoral students from underrepresented groups and about culturally responsive mentoring. These are called \"Sensemaking\" activities.<\/li>
                                5. Based on your findings from steps 2 and 3, work with your department head, graduate program director, and departmental diversity committee to draft a departmental plan with concrete steps for promoting the success of Black, Latino\/a, and Indigenous American doctoral students in completing the degree and preparing for faculty roles. Guidelines and examples are provided here.<\/li><\/ol>"},{"tab_title":"1. Slide deck for introducing the AGEP-NC project","tab_content":"

                                  This is an example slide deck for introducing faculty colleagues, department heads, and others to the AGEP-NC project. Tailor it to your own circumstances.<\/p>

                                  2021 AGEP-NC Orientation<\/a><\/span><\/p>","_id":"8c288d9"},{"tab_title":"2. Gather information about student pathways through doctoral program","tab_content":"

                                  Use these two checklists to collect information about how students move through your doctoral program and what difficulties they may encounter. The checklists also point to aspects of the program that might provide opportunities for change.<\/p>

                                  Doctoral Pathway Study Checklist<\/a><\/span><\/p>

                                  Baseline Information Checklist<\/a><\/span><\/p>","_id":"6dee2b1"},{"_id":"7b8b341","tab_title":"3. Surveys of Department Practices and Climate","tab_content":"

                                  Surveys of department practices and climate can give a picture of the perceptions of doctoral students and faculty at the beginning of the change process and at the end. The AGEP-NC survey instruments are provided in the next section of the toolkit. In this section we provide an example report of survey results that may be used as a template. It is important to report the results to the faculty and students so that they know that their voices are being heard. Sharing this information in a faculty meeting can also be a good catalyst for discussion.<\/p>

                                  Example Report on Doctoral Student Climate Survey Results<\/a><\/span><\/p>"},{"_id":"bb20b27","tab_title":"4. Sensemaking initiatives: Guidelines and examples","tab_content":"

                                  Guidelines for proposals for sensemaking initiatives<\/a><\/span><\/p>

                                  Example proposals for sensemaking initiatives<\/p>

                                  • Chemistry<\/a> <\/span><\/li>
                                  • Applied Ecology<\/a> <\/span><\/li>
                                  • Statistics<\/a> <\/span><\/li>
                                  • Poultry Science<\/a><\/span><\/li><\/ul>"},{"_id":"5a7432e","tab_title":"5. Departmental diversity plans: Guidelines and examples","tab_content":"

                                    Department plans to promote the success of Black, Latino\/a, and Indigenous American doctoral students in completing the PhD and preparing for faculty roles. These plans have been approved and adopted by AGEP-NC faculty fellows' departments.<\/p>

                                    Department Diversity Plan Guidelines<\/a><\/span><\/p>

                                    Video of a faculty fellow discussing the process his department used to develop their departmental plan.<\/a><\/span><\/p>

                                    Example plans<\/a><\/span><\/p>"}],"__globals__":{"tab_active_color":"globals\/colors?id=primary"}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"toggle"},{"id":"affa8e0","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Survey Instruments and Information","size":"medium","__globals__":{"title_color":"globals\/colors?id=secondary"}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"51f9dda","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"98272b8","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"8e85b24","elType":"widget","settings":{"tabs":[{"tab_title":"Climate and Practices Survey - Faculty Fellows ","tab_content":"

                                    When to administer:<\/strong> At the beginning and end of departmental participation in AGEP.<\/p>

                                    To whom:<\/strong> Department Faculty Fellows (those charged with leading the DEI initiatives in the department)<\/p>

                                    Administration: <\/strong>It is best for an outside consultant to administer and later clean the survey of any identifying information regarding the respondents. Due to the small number of Fellows generally participating, it may not be possible to avoid identifying them from their comments so extra caution must be used to prevent professional risk. Demographic information is not collected for this group.<\/p>

                                    Data sharing<\/strong>: The team of Fellows can use the information as a starting point for understanding landscape of diversity efforts in their departments and the progress they make over the time of their Fellowship.<\/p>

                                    Faculty Fellows Survey<\/a><\/p>","_id":"cdebae1"},{"tab_title":"Climate and Practices Survey - Doctoral Students in Participating Departments ","tab_content":"

                                    When to administer<\/strong>: At the beginning and end of departmental participation in AGEP or any time a department wishes to understand how students perceive issues related to diversity in their graduate programs.<\/p>

                                    To whom<\/strong>: Doctoral students in a department<\/p>

                                    Administration<\/strong>: To maximize response rate and reduce respondent anxiety, it is best for an outside consultant to administer and later clean the survey of any identifying information regarding the respondents. Student comments may reveal the identity of the author which, if shared verbatim, could put the author at risk in their program. Demographic information should likewise be handled with the utmost respect for the respondents' privacy and only collected and analyzed at the institution or very large sample size level where respondent identity can be protected.<\/p>

                                    Data sharing:<\/strong> The consultant can remove demographic data and share all other information with the department for deeper analysis. Data can be aggregated at the institution and alliance level for demographic analysis as well.<\/p>

                                    Survey for Department Doctoral Students<\/a><\/p>","_id":"66bfa77"},{"_id":"a888593","tab_title":"Climate and Practices Survey - Faculty in Participating Departments","tab_content":"

                                    When to administer:<\/strong> At the beginning and end of departmental participation in AGEP or any time a department wishes to understand how faculty perceive issues related to diversity in their graduate programs and faculty culture.<\/p>

                                    To whom:<\/strong> Graduate faculty in a department (i.e., faculty who may teach and advise doctoral students)<\/p>

                                    Administration<\/strong>: To maximize response rate and reduce respondent anxiety, it is best for an outside consultant to administer and later clean the survey of any identifying information regarding the respondents. Faculty comments may reveal the identity of the author which, if shared verbatim, could put the author at professional risk. Demographic information should likewise be handled with the utmost respect for the respondents' privacy and only collected and analyzed at the institution or very large sample size level where respondent identity can be protected.<\/p>

                                    Data sharing:<\/strong> The consultant can remove demographic data and share all other information with the department for deeper analysis. Data can be aggregated at the institution and alliance level for demographic analysis as well.<\/p>

                                    Department Faculty Survey<\/a><\/p>"},{"_id":"b191183","tab_title":"Climate and Practices Survey - Black, Hispanic and Indigenous American Students in All STEM Disciplines","tab_content":"

                                    When to administer<\/strong>: At the beginning and end of the AGEP grant period (in this case at a five year interval)<\/p>

                                    To whom<\/strong>: Black, Hispanic and Indigenous American doctoral students in STEM disciplines<\/p>

                                    Administration:<\/strong> To maximize response rate and reduce respondent anxiety, it is best for an outside consultant to administer and later clean the survey of any identifying information regarding the respondents. Student comments may reveal the identity of the author which, if shared verbatim, could put the author at risk in their program. Demographic information should likewise be handled with the utmost respect for the respondents' privacy and only collected and analyzed at the institution or very large sample size level where respondent identity can be protected.<\/p>

                                    Data sharing<\/strong>: The consultant can share the information at an institution level to help decision makers understand the climate for underrepresented doctoral students. If there are more than 5 respondents at a College or Department level, data can also be shared at that level.<\/p>

                                    URM Campus STEM Doctoral Student Survey<\/a><\/p>"},{"_id":"352ffae","tab_title":"Mentoring Research Survey, Focus Group and Interview Guides - Students","tab_content":"

                                    Research Focus Group Interview guide 8-22-18<\/a><\/p>

                                    Research Individual Doctoral Student Interview guide 8-22-18<\/a><\/p>

                                    Research Survey Doctoral Group 8-22-18<\/a><\/p>"},{"_id":"cb7af8e","tab_title":"Mentoring Research Survey and Interview Guide - Faculty, Department Heads, Graduate Program Directors","tab_content":"

                                    Mentoring Research Interview - Faculty, Graduate Program Director, Department Head<\/a><\/p>

                                    Mentoring Research Survey - Faculty Fellows<\/a><\/p>"},{"_id":"e31b16c","tab_title":"Recruitment Flyers for Mentoring Research Interviews and Focus Groups","tab_content":"

                                    Recruitment Flyer for Mentoring Research Interview<\/a><\/p>

                                    Recruitment Flyer for Mentoring Research Focus Group<\/a><\/p>"}],"__globals__":{"tab_active_color":"globals\/colors?id=primary"}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"toggle"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"c0add7d","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"9dd455e","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"fceb854","elType":"section","settings":{"content_position":"middle","structure":"20","border_border":"solid","__globals__":{"border_color":"globals\/colors?id=primary"}},"elements":[{"id":"adefe17","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":83.7819999999999964757080306299030780792236328125},"elements":[{"id":"58cd76d","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

item.title: AGEP-NC Publications

item.content:encoded:
AGEP-NC Model, Implementation and Evaluation

  •  Gumpertz M, Brent R, Campbell CD, Grasso M, Huet YM, Schimmel K. 2019. An Institutional Transformation Model to Increase Minority STEM doctoral Student Success. ASEE CoNECD Conference Proceedings, April 16, 2019, Crystal City, VA.
  • Schimmel KA, Campbell CD, Gumpertz M, Huet YM, Kelkar AD, Kizito JP. 2020. Departmental Initiatives across a University Alliance to Increase Minority STEM Doctoral Student Success. 2020 ASEE Annual Conference Proceedings. June 22-26, 2020. Virtual.
  • Grasso M and Campbell CD. 2020. A Change Model that Helps Faculty Mentor Underrepresented Minorities (URM) Doctoral Students for the STEM Professoriate. The Chronicle of Mentoring and Coaching. Special Issue 13 (1): 407- 412.
  • Brent CR, Schimmel KA,  and Gumpertz ML. 2021. How Do Departments Support their Underrepresented Minority Doctoral Students? Are they Doing Enough? ASEE CoNECD Conference Proceedings, Jan 24-28, 2021. Virtual.
  • Gumpertz, M., Foster, D., Grasso, M., & Huet, Y. M. (2022) Creating Continuous Change: Adapting an NSF ADVANCE Approach to the Development of the AGEP-NC Model of Institutional Transformation. The ADVANCE Journal, 3(1) May 16, 2022. https://doi.org/10.5399/osu/ADVJRNL.3.1.6

Research on Doctoral Student Mentoring

  • Sanczyk A, Douglas NC, Howell CD, and Merriweather LR. 2020. Experiences and Perceptions on Culturally Responsive STEM Doctoral Mentoring. Proceedings of  Hawaii International Conference on Education. Jan 3-7, 2020. Honolulu, HI.
  • Howell CD, Merriweather LR, Sanczyk A, Douglas N. 2020. Challenges in STEM PhD Programs: Biased Mentoring. Proceedings of 2020 IEEE Frontiers in Education Conference. Oct 21-24, 2020. Virtual.
  • Sanczyk A, Merriweather L, Douglas N, and Howell C. 2020.The Missing Pieces of Nurturing Students' Needs in Doctoral STEM Mentoring Relationships. London International Conference on Education Proceedings. Nov 23-25, 2020. Virtual.

  • Sanczyk A, Merriweather LR, Douglas N, and Howell CD. 2021. Cracks in Doctoral STEM Mentoring Relationships: Students' Perceptions. International Journal for Cross-Disciplinary Subjects in Education. 12(1): 4362-4368.

  • Sanczyk A, Merriweather LR, Douglas N and Howell CD. 2021. STEM Doctoral Mentoring: A Call for a Conscious, Culturally Responsive Journey. International Journal of Mentoring and Coaching in Education, 10(3): 284-297.

Out with the Old, In with the New: What the National Academies of Science, Engineering, and Medicine Got Right about STEM Doctoral Mentoring. Inclusive Education and Lifelong Learning  Volume 1.  Infonomic Society.  London.  DOI: 10.20533/978-1-913572-45-7_4.

item.title: AGEP-NC Videos
item.dc:creator: gumpertz
item.content:encoded:
These videos feature members of the AGEP-NC community providing their perspectives on different aspects of promoting diversity, equity and inclusion in STEM doctoral programs.

AGEP-NC Overview

This video gives a 3-minute outline of the aims, approach and progress of the AGEP-NC project. It was created for the 2021 STEM for All Video Showcase.

https://youtu.be/xsifav8_USg
Juan Vivero-Escoto on Teaching STEM at the University Level

Juan Vivero-Escoto, associate professor of Chemistry at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte. In this video, Dr. Vivero-Escoto discusses his career path and what he enjoys about teaching chemistry at the university level. He also shares his recommendations for minority groups interested in teaching positions in STEM or those considering advanced degrees.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L4fVsPaA5Ts
Reginald Goodwin on Pursuing a Graduate Degree Later in Life

Reggie Goodwin, Student Leadership Council Member, recent PhD in Nanoengineering, NC A&T and UNCG Joint School of Nanoscience and Nanoengineering. In this video, Dr. Reginald Goodwin discusses his career path and experience returning to NC A&T to earn his master's and PhD in nanoengineering. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zV-0UJ32sGc&t=23s
An Associate Professor's Career Path

Andrea Ofori-Boadu, AGEP-NC Fellow, Associate Professor of Built Environment, North Carolina A&T State University, describes the path she took to becoming a faculty member and the expectations of new faculty members. She shares what her typical day involves and the highlights of her chosen profession.

https://youtu.be/VLcxgs7mvTE
Developing a Department Plan

Adam Reitzel, AGEP-NC Fellow, Professor and Graduate Program Coordinator, Biological Sciences Department, UNC Charlotte discusses the steps leading up to his department plan. Key steps included introducing the idea of developing a plan at a faculty meeting, brainstorming with his department chair and departmental DEI committee, sharing ideas with other AGEP-NC faculty fellows, and multiple open discussions with graduate students, postdocs and faculty in his department.

https://youtu.be/ioKssBqrNNM
A Student's Perspective

Ebony Gaillard, Student Leadership Council Member, Doctoral Student in Biology, UNC Charlotte, gives details about her background, studies, and experience in AGEP-NC. She gives her experience in her department, hurdles doctoral students face, and what changes could be made.

https://youtu.be/V3lX8YGRWeA
A College Values Statement

Fatma Mili, Dean of the College of Computing and Informatics at UNC Charlotte, explains how her college went about creating a College Values Statement, whose vision is "A World with Equity in Computing and Humanity in Technology". She discusses the agency that faculty have and the imperative that we exercise our power.

https://youtu.be/n6pEgkp_G1A
Engaging Faculty in Sensemaking

Derek Aday, Department Head of Applied Ecology, NC State University, discusses department culture and the roles of faculty in the department and a departmental Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Committee who have taken leadership roles in recruiting diverse graduate students and faculty and developing an equitable and welcoming department climate.

https://youtu.be/fT2m0lCaFWA
Department Plans for Recruiting and Retaining Diverse Faculty

Jeff Braden, Dean of the College of Humanities and Social Sciences, NC State, explains how formal departmental plans to recruit and retain diverse faculty have, in just a few years, had a dramatic effect on the composition of faculty in his college.

https://youtu.be/l0enlT__CQU
Charging a Faculty Search Committee

This video, of an actual search committee meeting, shows Jeff Braden, Dean of the College of Humanities and Social Sciences, NC State, discussing NC State's commitment to diversity and explaining how unconscious bias can affect search committee deliberations.

https://youtu.be/FKULqcZYbGs

Presentations from AGEP-NC Alliance Meetings and Webinars

  • Workshop: Leadership and Change Strategies for Campus Diversity, Adrianna Kezar, Professor for Higher Education, University of Southern California and co-director of the Pullias Center for Higher Education. Webinar Part I Recording.  Part II: Culture Change Recording
  • Workshop: Taking Action for Change – Supporting the Thriving of URM Scholars in Higher Education. Robbin Chapman, Associate Dean for Diversity, Inclusion and Belonging at Harvard Kennedy School
    • Workshop Part I Video Recording
    • Workshop Part II Video Recording

  • Webinar: Do Faculty Diversity Programs Work? Evidence from 600 Universities, 1993-2015. Frank Dobbin, Henry Ford II Professor of the Social Sciences, Sociology Department Chair, Harvard University. Webinar recording

  • Keynote address: Strategies for Planning, Implementing and Evaluating Department DEI Initiatives. Ayesha Boyce, UNC Greensboro. Video of the Presentation

  • Alumni Perspective: Perspectives on Mentoring for Fortifying a Future in Academia. Kristen Rhinehardt, North Carolina A&T State University. Video of the Presentation

  • Webinar:A Model for Dramatically Increasing Diversity at the PhD Level in STEM. Keivan Gaudalupe Stassun, Stevenson Professor of Physics and Astronomy, Vanderbilt University. Webinar recording
  • Race Really Matters. David Asai, Senior Director, Science Education, Howard Hughes Medical Institute. Video recording.
  • Workshop I.The Absence of Diversity Hurts Everyone; II. Accountability. Karen L. Dace, Vice Chancellor, Division of Diversity, Equity and Inclusion, IUPUI. Video recording.
  • The importance of Identity in the Success of Students from Minoritized Communities. Manuel Pérez-Quiñones, Professor of Software and Information Systems, UNC Charlotte. Video Recording
  • The Language of Othering: Unlearning the ABCs. Lisa Merriweather, Professor of Adult Education, UNC Charlotte. Video Recording
  • Webinar: Using Evaluation for Decision Making and Improvement. Leslie Goodyear, Education Development Center.  Video Recording
  • 2023 Winter Alliance Meeting. UNC Charlotte.
    • Video Recording_1
    • Video Recording_2

This material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation under Grant Nos. 1820536 1820538 and 1820582. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this material are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation.

Recorded Webinar https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L4fVsPaA5Ts

Reggie Goodwin, Student Leadership Council Member, recent PhD in Nanoengineering, NC A&T and UNCG Joint School of Nanoscience and Nanoengineering. In this video, Dr. Reginald Goodwin discusses his career path and experience returning to NC A&T to earn his master's and PhD in nanoengineering. 

"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false},{"id":"5e333b4","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"de78341","elType":"widget","settings":{"youtube_url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zV-0UJ32sGc&t=23s","vimeo_url":"https://vimeo.com/235215203","dailymotion_url":"https://www.dailymotion.com/video/x6tqhqb"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"video"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"8f558e6","elType":"section","settings":{"structure":"20","border_border":"solid","border_width":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"1","left":"0","isLinked":false},"__globals__":{"border_color":"globals/colors?id=primary"}},"elements":[{"id":"d8f5bfa","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"1a9455b","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"An Associate Professor's Career Path
","header_size":"h5"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"60fbaeb","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Andrea Ofori-Boadu, AGEP-NC Fellow, Associate Professor of Built Environment, North Carolina A&T State University, describes the path she took to becoming a faculty member and the expectations of new faculty members. She shares what her typical day involves and the highlights of her chosen profession.

"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false},{"id":"b5f149e","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"69410de","elType":"widget","settings":{"youtube_url":"https://youtu.be/VLcxgs7mvTE","vimeo_url":"https://vimeo.com/235215203","dailymotion_url":"https://www.dailymotion.com/video/x6tqhqb"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"video"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"4b66e11","elType":"section","settings":{"structure":"20","content_position":"middle","border_border":"solid","border_width":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"1","left":"0","isLinked":false},"__globals__":{"border_color":"globals/colors?id=primary"}},"elements":[{"id":"517edb8","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"8b2c399","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Developing a Department Plan
","header_size":"h5"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"2cef64d","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Adam Reitzel, AGEP-NC Fellow, Professor and Graduate Program Coordinator, Biological Sciences Department, UNC Charlotte discusses the steps leading up to his department plan. Key steps included introducing the idea of developing a plan at a faculty meeting, brainstorming with his department chair and departmental DEI committee, sharing ideas with other AGEP-NC faculty fellows, and multiple open discussions with graduate students, postdocs and faculty in his department.

"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false},{"id":"96d60c2","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"c18a236","elType":"widget","settings":{"youtube_url":"https://youtu.be/ioKssBqrNNM","vimeo_url":"https://vimeo.com/235215203","dailymotion_url":"https://www.dailymotion.com/video/x6tqhqb"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"video"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"6495881","elType":"section","settings":{"structure":"20","content_position":"middle","border_border":"solid","border_width":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"1","left":"0","isLinked":false},"__globals__":{"border_color":"globals/colors?id=primary"}},"elements":[{"id":"36d1011","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"0472344","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"A Student's Perspective","header_size":"h5"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"94c0394","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Ebony Gaillard, Student Leadership Council Member, Doctoral Student in Biology, UNC Charlotte, gives details about her background, studies, and experience in AGEP-NC. She gives her experience in her department, hurdles doctoral students face, and what changes could be made.

"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false},{"id":"c7754ff","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"eecaaba","elType":"widget","settings":{"youtube_url":"https://youtu.be/V3lX8YGRWeA","vimeo_url":"https://vimeo.com/235215203","dailymotion_url":"https://www.dailymotion.com/video/x6tqhqb"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"video"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"40ca730","elType":"section","settings":{"structure":"20","content_position":"middle","border_border":"solid","border_width":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"1","left":"0","isLinked":false},"__globals__":{"border_color":"globals/colors?id=primary"}},"elements":[{"id":"aa6ad74","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"5f152db","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"A College Values Statement
","header_size":"h5"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"e258630","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Fatma Mili, Dean of the College of Computing and Informatics at UNC Charlotte, explains how her college went about creating a College Values Statement, whose vision is "A World with Equity in Computing and Humanity in Technology". She discusses the agency that faculty have and the imperative that we exercise our power.

"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false},{"id":"f31215a","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"02f5b80","elType":"widget","settings":{"youtube_url":"https://youtu.be/n6pEgkp_G1A","vimeo_url":"https://vimeo.com/235215203","dailymotion_url":"https://www.dailymotion.com/video/x6tqhqb"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"video"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"2241b0c","elType":"section","settings":{"structure":"20","content_position":"middle","border_border":"solid","border_width":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"1","left":"0","isLinked":false},"__globals__":{"border_color":"globals/colors?id=primary"}},"elements":[{"id":"bcf2f90","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"6026c5b","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Engaging Faculty in Sensemaking
","header_size":"h5"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"7c8029b","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Derek Aday, Department Head of Applied Ecology, NC State University, discusses department culture and the roles of faculty in the department and a departmental Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Committee who have taken leadership roles in recruiting diverse graduate students and faculty and developing an equitable and welcoming department climate.

"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false},{"id":"3cd29a9","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"43ff96e","elType":"widget","settings":{"youtube_url":"https://youtu.be/fT2m0lCaFWA","vimeo_url":"https://vimeo.com/235215203","dailymotion_url":"https://www.dailymotion.com/video/x6tqhqb"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"video"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"650473f","elType":"section","settings":{"structure":"20","border_border":"solid","border_width":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"1","left":"0","isLinked":false},"__globals__":{"border_color":"globals/colors?id=primary"}},"elements":[{"id":"8e0b339","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"c8ead09","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Department Plans for Recruiting and Retaining Diverse Faculty
","header_size":"h5"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"85d028a","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

Jeff Braden, Dean of the College of Humanities and Social Sciences, NC State, explains how formal departmental plans to recruit and retain diverse faculty have, in just a few years, had a dramatic effect on the composition of faculty in his college.

"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false},{"id":"2b9d4a2","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"64a7300","elType":"widget","settings":{"youtube_url":"https://youtu.be/l0enlT__CQU","vimeo_url":"https://vimeo.com/235215203","dailymotion_url":"https://www.dailymotion.com/video/x6tqhqb"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"video"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"b99f45e","elType":"section","settings":{"structure":"20","border_border":"solid","border_width":{"unit":"px","top":"0","right":"0","bottom":"1","left":"0","isLinked":false},"__globals__":{"border_color":"globals/colors?id=primary"}},"elements":[{"id":"4b1ee08","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"53eaa8a","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Charging a Faculty Search Committee","header_size":"h5"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"ead9960","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"

This video, of an actual search committee meeting, shows Jeff Braden, Dean of the College of Humanities and Social Sciences, NC State, discussing NC State's commitment to diversity and explaining how unconscious bias can affect search committee deliberations.

"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"text-editor"}],"isInner":false},{"id":"95849fd","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":50,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"276aa6d","elType":"widget","settings":{"youtube_url":"https://youtu.be/FKULqcZYbGs","vimeo_url":"https://vimeo.com/235215203","dailymotion_url":"https://www.dailymotion.com/video/x6tqhqb"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"video"}],"isInner":false}],"isInner":false},{"id":"370980d","elType":"section","settings":[],"elements":[{"id":"7d10b1a","elType":"column","settings":{"_column_size":100,"_inline_size":null},"elements":[{"id":"ebd96b3","elType":"widget","settings":{"space":{"unit":"px","size":15,"sizes":[]}},"elements":[],"widgetType":"spacer"},{"id":"c2ebe12","elType":"widget","settings":{"title":"Presentations from AGEP-NC Alliance Meetings and Webinars","header_size":"h4"},"elements":[],"widgetType":"heading"},{"id":"4eb0b89","elType":"widget","settings":{"editor":"
  • Workshop: Leadership and Change Strategies for Campus Diversity, Adrianna Kezar, Professor for Higher Education, University of Southern California and co-director of the Pullias Center for Higher Education. Webinar Part I Recording.  Part II: Culture Change Recording
  • Workshop: Taking Action for Change – Supporting the Thriving of URM Scholars in Higher Education. Robbin Chapman, Associate Dean for Diversity, Inclusion and Belonging at Harvard Kennedy School
    • Workshop Part I Video Recording
    • Workshop Part II Video Recording

  • Webinar: Do Faculty Diversity Programs Work? Evidence from 600 Universities, 1993-2015. Frank Dobbin, Henry Ford II Professor of the Social Sciences, Sociology Department Chair, Harvard University. Webinar recording

  • Keynote address: Strategies for Planning, Implementing and Evaluating Department DEI Initiatives. Ayesha Boyce, UNC Greensboro. Video of the Presentation

  • Alumni Perspective: Perspectives on Mentoring for Fortifying a Future in Academia. Kristen Rhinehardt, North Carolina A&T State University. Video of the Presentation

  • Webinar:A Model for Dramatically Increasing Diversity at the PhD Level in STEM. Keivan Gaudalupe Stassun, Stevenson Professor of Physics and Astronomy, Vanderbilt University. Webinar recording
  • Race Really Matters. David Asai, Senior Director, Science Education, Howard Hughes Medical Institute. Video recording.
  • Workshop I.The Absence of Diversity Hurts Everyone; II. Accountability. Karen L. Dace, Vice Chancellor, Division of Diversity, Equity and Inclusion, IUPUI. Video recording.
  • The importance of Identity in the Success of Students from Minoritized Communities. Manuel Pérez-Quiñones, Professor of Software and Information Systems, UNC Charlotte. Video Recording
  • The Language of Othering: Unlearning the ABCs. Lisa Merriweather, Professor of Adult Education, UNC Charlotte. Video Recording
  • Webinar: Using Evaluation for Decision Making and Improvement. Leslie Goodyear, Education Development Center.  Video Recording
  • 2023 Winter Alliance Meeting. UNC Charlotte.
    • Video Recording_1
    • Video Recording_2

item.title: Library of Reading Matter and Videos on Diversity in Doctoral Education
item.dc:creator: gumpertz
item.content:encoded:
Reading matter, videos, and presentations on mentoring, the experiences of underrepresented minority graduate students, promoting diversity and inclusion in graduate programs, and making institutional change.

Mentoring

  • Joel Ducoste's Symposium - Fostering a Mentoring CultureMeeting slides
  • Mentoring Guide: A Guide for Mentors
  • Mentoring: Creating Mutually Empowering Relationships
  • From Deficits to Possibilities: Mentoring Lessons from Plants on Cultivating Individual Growth through Environmental Assessment and Optimization
  • National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine: The Science of Effective Mentorship in STEMM
  • The Missing Pieces of Nurturing Students' Needs in Doctoral STEM  Mentoring  Relationships
  • The Thrive Mosaic Developmental Framework: A Systems Activist Approach to Marginalized STEM Scholar Success
  • To support or to deny: mentoring or gatekeeping?
  • Mentoring beyond hierarchies: Multi-mentor systems and models.
  • The Science of Mentorship podcasts.
  • Supporting Faculty Peer Mentoring Symposium 
    • Meeting Slides 

Tools for Mentors

  • Teaching Module on Communication Styles for Mentors and Mentees
  • myIDP
  • Video:  Find Your Career Fit - Self Assessment using myIDP.
  • Effective Communication: Excellence in a Technical Presentation

Experiences of Minority Graduate Students

  • Underrepresented Racial and/or Ethnic Minority (URM) Graduate Students in STEM Disciplines: A Critical Approach to Understanding Graduate School Experiences and Obstacles to Degree Progression
  • Rooted in the Soil: The Social Experiences of Black Graduate Students at a Southern Research University
  • Assimilating the "Culture of No Culture" in Science: Feminist Interventions in (De)Mentoring Graduate Women 
  • Reimbursement Policies Make Academia Less Inclusive. 
  • Living Proof: Stories of Resilience Along the Mathematical Journey
  • June 17, 2020, Statement from the NC State Black Graduate Student Association (BGSA)

Promoting Institutional Change

  • Examining the Institutional Transformation Process: The Importance of Sensemaking, Interrelated Strategies, and Balance
  • Video: Culture Change and Competing Priorities. Adrianna Kezar
  • Structure and Belonging: Pathways to Success for Underrepresented Minority and Women PhD Students in STEM Fields
  • Creating a Diverse Student Success Infrastructure: The Key to Catalyzing Cultural Change for Today’s Student
  • Making Academic Change Happen
  • Creating Shared Vision
  • Communicating Change
  • Forming and Developing Teams
  • Creating Strategic Partnerships
  • Implicit Theories of Change as a Barrier to Change on College Campuses:An Examination of STEM Reform.
  • Role of trust in graduate programs. Claude Steele video. Minute 34:33-48:45 of Session 10
    • The session is a panel discussion titled "Promising programs, practices, characteristics and components for systemic change" chaired by Darryl Monteau.
  • The Fisk-Vanderbilt Master’s-to-Ph.D. Bridge Program: Recognizing, enlisting, and cultivating unrealized or unrecognized potential in underrepresented minority students
  • Immunity to Change
  • 'Tackling the Challenges of Our Time Requires All of Us to Be at the Table'
  • Community Readiness
  • The Change Leadership Toolkit: A Guide for Advancing Systemic Change in Higher Education

Graduate Education and Diversity

  • Underrepresented Faculty Play a Disproportionate Role in Advancing Diversity and Inclusion
  • Making Invisible Work in STEM More Visible
  • The Committee on Equal Opportunities in Science and Engineering Biennial Reports to Congress
  • National Academy of Sciences report on Graduate STEM Education for the 21st Century. Summary, Chapters 2 and 3
  • Scaling Improvement in STEM Learning Environments: The Strategic Role of a National Organization
  • How the Opaque Way We Hire Postdocs Contributes to Science’s Diversity Problem
  • Bait and Switch: Representation, Climate, and Tensions of Diversity Work in Graduate Education
  • Higher Ed's Most Common Rationale for Diversity Favors White Students More than Black

Institutional Bias

  • Institutional Bias, Chapter by P.J.Henry
  • Maunakea: Redirecting the Lens onto the Culture of Mainstream Science
  • To Learn Inclusion Skills, Make it Personal

This material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation under Grant Nos. 1820536 1820538 and 1820582. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this material are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation.

item.title: AGEP-NC Fellows
item.dc:creator: gumpertz
item.content:encoded:
About

AGEP-NC (North Carolina Alliances for Graduate Education and the Professoriate) Fellows serve two year terms learning about cross cultural mentoring, promoting diversity in doctoral programs, and facilitating departmental dialog.

Roles & Responsibilities

  • Fellows develop initiatives to raise awareness, promote buy-in and build cross-cultural and mentoring skills among the faculty in their department;
  • Engage the faculty in designing approaches to address obstacles for students and the needs of faculty for creating pathways for success for diverse dissertation students;
  • Coordinate a faculty process of developing a departmental plan for doctoral student diversity and inclusion.

 

Cohort 1 AGEP-NC Fellows

NC A&T (2019 - 2021)

NC State (2018 - 2020)

UNC Charlotte (2019 - 2021)

Cohort 2 AGEP-NC Fellows (2020-2022)

NC A&T

NC State

UNC Charlotte

Cohort 3 AGEP-NC Fellows

NC A&T (2023 - 2025)

NC State (2021-2023)

Past AGEP-NC Fellows
